commands.createtask¶

Classes¶

CreateTask

This class handles task creation functionality, including user assignment and

Module Contents¶

class commands.createtask.CreateTask(users=[])[source]¶

This class handles task creation functionality, including user assignment and Slack-compatible response generation to confirm task creation.

Why: Motivation for use cases where automated task creation and assignment are needed, especially in environments leveraging Slack for task management, making it easier to create, assign, and confirm tasks within a collaborative workspace.

How: Common usage examples: 1. CreateTask.create_task_input_blocks(): Prepares the Slack-compatible input UI for task details. 2. CreateTask.create_task(desc, points, deadline, assignee, created_by): Creates a task with

specified attributes and stores it in the database.

base_create_task_block_format[source]¶
greetings = ['Awesome', 'Great', 'Congratulations', 'Well done', "Let's go"][source]¶
payload[source]¶
users[source]¶
create_task_input_blocks()[source]¶

Creates a list of Slack-compatible input blocks for task creation.

Returns:

A list of blocks, each representing an input field or button.

Return type:

list

Why: This function provides Slack’s interactive message structure, allowing users to input task details like description, deadline, points, and assignees in a standardized format. How: Example usage - ` blocks = task_creator.create_task_input_blocks() `

create_task(desc, points, deadline, assignee, created_by)[source]¶

Creates a task in the database and prepares a success message with task ID.

Parameters:

  • desc (str) – Description of task

  • points (int) – Points of task

  • deadline (Date) – Deadline of task

  • assignee (str) – User ID of the assignee

  • created_by (str) – User ID of the creator

Returns:

Response blocks and Task ID

Return type:

tuple(list, int)

Why: Provides an efficient way to manage task records in the database, while generating a Slack-friendly confirmation message for the task creator. How: Example usage - ` response, task_id = task_creator.create_task("New feature", 3, "2023-12-01", "U67890", "U12345") `
